Award.AwardTitle: Designing Highly Polar Self-Assembled Molecular Piezoelectric Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Recent advances in flexible electronics offer tremendous promise for lightweight devices, enabling applications from mobile computing to medical implants. Simultaneously, the demand for portable energy solutions has risen, since integrated energy storage or conversion is critical to power these technologies. Mechanical energy is ubiquitous but challenging to use effectively. Capturing this inexpensive and readily available energy source by converting between mechanical force and electrical current can lead to innovative advances such as self-powered sensors for touch, vibration or force, or flexible touch screens. Existing materials used to harvest mechanical energy are often inflexible, brittle, and hard to process. The vast potential applications, coupled with key limitations of current materials, create a compelling need for a new perspective on the conversion of mechanical energy, from the bottom up. With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program, this project focuses on fundamental understanding and optimizing these materials first as molecules, then as single molecular layers, and then in films and devices. The result will be a new family of flexible, compressible materials for microscale energy generation and energy harvesting. Beyond the research component, the project provides training to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in both the interdisciplinary field of nanomaterials and the combination of experimental and computational research.

Technical Abstract
This collaborative project integrates synthesis, characterization, and simulation-driven materials design to develop a family of molecular solid piezoelectric materials for energy harvesting applications. The central hypothesis underlying the research is that directed self-assembly of conformationally-driven molecular piezoelectrics based on peptides and related bio-inspired oligomers leads to materials with far superior characteristics (piezo response, electrical properties, flexibility) than current piezo materials. The project builds on an existing collaboration and strong preliminary results that predict high piezo response from conformational changes of polar molecules in an applied electric field. The project advances the synthesis, modeling, and characterization of new electroresponsive bio-inspired materials. At each stage, the research identifies responsive molecular targets as well as the properties needed to produce optimal layers and films. These results contribute to the fundamental understanding of electromechanical properties of biomaterials, including accurate geometries of molecules in the condensed phase surrounded by nanoscale electric fields, such as ions or dipoles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent advances in flexible electronics offer tremendous promise for lightweight devices, enabling applications from mobile computing to medical implants. Simultaneously, the demand for portable energy solutions has risen, since integrated energy storage or conversion is critical to power these technologies. Mechanical energy is ubiquitous but challenging to use effectively. Capturing this inexpensive and readily available energy source by converting between mechanical force and electrical current can lead to innovative advances such as self-powered sensors for touch, vibration or force, or flexible touch screens.  Existing materials used to harvest mechanical energy are often inflexible, brittle, and hard to process. The vast potential applications, coupled with key limitations of current materials, create a compelling need for new kinds of electromechanical materials.


The overall goal of this project was to improve fundamental understanding and optimizing molecular-based piezoelectric materials first as molecules, then as single molecular layers, and then in films and devices. Over the three-year project period, nanoscale electromechanical characterization and synthetic chemistry proved that single-molecule monolayers yield measurable response, suggesting more flexible molecules are key targets for future investigation. A new kind of atomic force microscopy was developed to reliably determine both electromechanical and electrostatic response of these films. New synthetic techniques have been developed to prepare peptide-functionalized monolayers with tailored density and background surface polarity – resulting in different surface compositions that can modulate protein behavior. Computational results also demonstrated the atomic-scale fundamental response of hydrogen bonds and peptide oligomers to electric fields, in some cases surprisingly contracting in response to applied fields. These results point to new avenues of molecular and materials design with a significantly increased electromechanical response with potential for new applications.


Research efforts in pursuit of the project goals contributed to the education of four graduate students, two undergraduate students, and two high school students from the diverse student population at Pittsburgh Allderdice, all who were directly involved in the work. These students gained skills in an interdisciplinary mix of synthetic chemistry, computational modeling, and surface and nanoscale characterization. In other efforts, the PIs developed curriculum for teaching the effective communication of scientific research and presented this in several forms to >100 scientists and scientists-in-training from the PI’s University and beyond. In outreach to the broader public, the PIs volunteered for various activities with a local science museum aimed at educating local K-12 students on careers in chemistry, as well as participating in multiple “Skype a Scientist” outreach with K-8 students nationwide.
